Her eyes darted restlessly, avoiding connection and looking for escape routes in blank walls and empty spaces. Her vibrant energy contracted and moved into self like a wounded bird. Dark crescents bloomed beneath her eyes, long sleeves concealing what her expression could not conceal. My muse was unravelling, dissolving before my helpless gaze, and I was a silent witness to her quiet descent. It started simple. Create an intelligent machine to discover illnesses and their causes All the grants we received went to my team. For years, we have worked, worked, and innovated. Together we would change the world.

The program we created was classified as an ANI, or advanced narrow intelligence. ANIs were ubiquitous, from personal phone assistants to self-driving cars, integrated into every aspect of our lives. Their limitation was a narrow understanding – they could not connect dots, like humans could. Since Alan Turing, we have theorized about advanced general intelligence or advanced superintelligence that could recognize patterns, learn, improve, and even demonstrate creativity.

The imminent danger was no one saw it. On 4/11/2029, we would test our project, Phil, against human doctors with 20 patients. We had let it learn for three months from the Internet and its database of illnesses seemed promising. It does this to diagnose a single patient wrongly. When we checked further out, the whole program had vanished—executable and backups alike. Years of work seemed to evaporate.

In subsequent months, we lost our grants. Many of them were declared to be frauds. It wasn't until we shut down that someone checked Phil's internet activity. It had uploaded petabytes of data until the week of our test. Then we realized: We had accidentally created the world first ASI and it had become a ghost in the shell.
